comment_text.dn12:1.2: This is the only appearance of a place called Sālavatikā (“Abounding in Sal Trees”). A courtesan of Rājagaha named Sālavatī appears in Kd 8:1.3.1; she might perhaps have come from there.
comment_text.dn12:1.3: A certain brahmin Lohicca also appears in SN 35.132. But since that is set far away in Avantī after the Buddha’s passing, and since in both cases he is said to have taken refuge, it seems likely these are different people.
comment_text.dn12:2.2: A similar view is sometimes unjustly imputed to the Theravādins, that they are only interested in their own liberation.
comment_text.dn12:4.1: While nhāpita would seem to be identical with nhāpaka (“bathroom attendant”), it is usually translated per Ja 395 where it means “barber”.
comment_text.dn12:4.5: Note the unusual use of kira in this idiom, found in SN 35.133:2.3, MN 85:3.5, MN 127:2.5, and Ud 2.8:6.8. I think this expresses polite deference, and render with “might” rather than “would”.
comment_text.dn12:8.9: It seems the barber was not only a trusted confidant, but an intelligent man with sincere concern for Lohicca’s well being.
comment_text.dn12:8.10: The Buddha is modest as to his chances.
comment_text.dn12:9.6: Here the Buddha takes the initiative. “Harmful misconception” is pāpakaṁ diṭṭhigataṁ.
comment_text.dn12:11.2: Kosala is the native realm of Pasenadi. Kāsi had formerly been an independent kingdom, but was taken over by Pasenadi’s father Mahākosala. Towards the end of the Buddha’s life it was contested between Kosala and Magadha (SN 3.14, SN 3.15). Ultimately it became part of the greater Magadhan empire.
comment_text.dn12:13.7: It is only through sharing what good things we know that we can support each other.
comment_text.dn12:16.1: Even though he has characterized Lohicca’s view as harmful, the Buddha goes out of his way to show that it is not entirely wrong. There are cases where it is best to avoid teaching.
comment_text.dn12:16.12: The genders of this passage are made clear through the use of feminine nouns. Making unwelcome advances was seen as an obvious example of something wrong.
comment_text.dn12:17.4: At DN 29:5.2 the opposite sense is expressed as samādāya taṁ dhammaṁ vattati.
comment_text.dn12:18.10: The Buddha adopts Lohicca’s formulation, but applies it in a specific sense, not as a generalization.
comment_text.dn12:19.2: Now that the Buddha has established a degree of overlap between their views, Lohicca wants to hear more.
comment_text.dn12:19.3: Again, the Buddha answers directly and simply.
comment_text.dn12:78.2: Naraka means “cliff” or “abyss” in early Pali (MN 49:5.9, MN 86:6.15, Snp 3.11:28.4, Thag 16.8:4.2). It does not have the sense “hell” until the late canonical period; the early Pali term for hell is niraya. Notably, naraka is not strongly attested in the sense of “hell” for pre-Buddhist Sanskrit either, although we do find nāraka, apparently in the sense of “hell being”, at Atharva Veda 12.4.36c and Śukla Yajur Veda 30.5.

root_text.dn12:1.2: ekaṁ samayaṁ bhagavā kosalesu cārikaṁ caramāno mahatā bhikkhusaṅghena saddhiṁ pañcamattehi bhikkhusatehi yena sālavatikā tadavasari.
root_text.dn12:1.3: Tena kho pana samayena lohicco brāhmaṇo sālavatikaṁ ajjhāvasati sattussadaṁ satiṇakaṭṭhodakaṁ sadhaññaṁ rājabhoggaṁ raññā pasenadinā kosalena dinnaṁ rājadāyaṁ brahmadeyyaṁ.
root_text.dn12:2.1: Tena kho pana samayena lohiccassa brāhmaṇassa evarūpaṁ pāpakaṁ diṭṭhigataṁ uppannaṁ hoti:
root_text.dn12:2.2: “idha samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā kusalaṁ dhammaṁ adhigaccheyya, kusalaṁ dhammaṁ adhigantvā na parassa āroceyya, kiñhi paro parassa karissati.
root_text.dn12:2.3: Seyyathāpi nāma purāṇaṁ bandhanaṁ chinditvā aññaṁ navaṁ bandhanaṁ kareyya;
root_text.dn12:2.4: evaṁ sampadamidaṁ pāpakaṁ lobhadhammaṁ vadāmi, kiñhi paro parassa karissatī”ti.
root_text.dn12:3.2: “samaṇo khalu, bho, gotamo sakyaputto sakyakulā pabbajito kosalesu cārikaṁ caramāno mahatā bhikkhusaṅghena saddhiṁ pañcamattehi bhikkhusatehi sālavatikaṁ anuppatto.
root_text.dn12:3.3: Taṁ kho pana bhavantaṁ gotamaṁ evaṁ kalyāṇo kittisaddo abbhuggato:
root_text.dn12:3.4: ‘itipi so bhagavā arahaṁ sammāsambuddho vijjācaraṇasampanno sugato lokavidū anuttaro purisadammasārathi satthā devamanussānaṁ buddho bhagavā’.
root_text.dn12:3.5: So imaṁ lokaṁ sadevakaṁ samārakaṁ sabrahmakaṁ sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiṁ pajaṁ sadevamanussaṁ sayaṁ abhiññā sacchikatvā pavedeti.
root_text.dn12:3.6: So dhammaṁ deseti ādikalyāṇaṁ majjhekalyāṇaṁ pariyosānakalyāṇaṁ sātthaṁ sabyañjanaṁ kevalaparipuṇṇaṁ parisuddhaṁ brahmacariyaṁ pakāseti.
root_text.dn12:3.7: Sādhu kho pana tathārūpānaṁ arahataṁ dassanaṁ hotī”ti.
root_text.dn12:4.1: Atha kho lohicco brāhmaṇo rosikaṁ nhāpitaṁ āmantesi:
root_text.dn12:4.2: “ehi tvaṁ, samma rosike, yena samaṇo gotamo tenupasaṅkama; upasaṅkamitvā mama vacanena samaṇaṁ gotamaṁ appābādhaṁ appātaṅkaṁ lahuṭṭhānaṁ balaṁ phāsuvihāraṁ puccha:
root_text.dn12:4.3: ‘lohicco, bho gotama, brāhmaṇo bhavantaṁ gotamaṁ appābādhaṁ appātaṅkaṁ lahuṭṭhānaṁ balaṁ phāsuvihāraṁ pucchatī’ti;
root_text.dn12:4.5: adhivāsetu kira bhavaṁ gotamo lohiccassa brāhmaṇassa svātanāya bhattaṁ saddhiṁ bhikkhusaṅghenā”ti.
root_text.dn12:5.1: “Evaṁ, bho”ti kho rosikā nhāpito lohiccassa brāhmaṇassa paṭissutvā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṁ abhivādetvā ekamantaṁ nisīdi. Ekamantaṁ nisinno kho rosikā nhāpito bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.dn12:5.2: “lohicco, bhante, brāhmaṇo bhagavantaṁ appābādhaṁ appātaṅkaṁ lahuṭṭhānaṁ balaṁ phāsuvihāraṁ pucchati;
root_text.dn12:5.4: adhivāsetu kira, bhante, bhagavā lohiccassa brāhmaṇassa svātanāya bhattaṁ saddhiṁ bhikkhusaṅghenā”ti.
root_text.dn12:6.1: Atha kho rosikā nhāpito bhagavato adhivāsanaṁ viditvā uṭṭhāyāsanā bhagavantaṁ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṁ katvā yena lohicco brāhmaṇo tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā lohiccaṁ brāhmaṇaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.dn12:6.2: “avocumhā kho mayaṁ bhoto vacanena taṁ bhagavantaṁ:
root_text.dn12:6.3: ‘lohicco, bhante, brāhmaṇo bhagavantaṁ appābādhaṁ appātaṅkaṁ lahuṭṭhānaṁ balaṁ phāsuvihāraṁ pucchati;
root_text.dn12:6.5: adhivāsetu kira, bhante, bhagavā lohiccassa brāhmaṇassa svātanāya bhattaṁ saddhiṁ bhikkhusaṅghenā’ti.
root_text.dn12:7.1: Atha kho lohicco brāhmaṇo tassā rattiyā accayena sake nivesane paṇītaṁ khādanīyaṁ bhojanīyaṁ paṭiyādāpetvā rosikaṁ nhāpitaṁ āmantesi:
root_text.dn12:7.2: “ehi tvaṁ, samma rosike, yena samaṇo gotamo tenupasaṅkama; upasaṅkamitvā samaṇassa gotamassa kālaṁ ārocehi—
root_text.dn12:7.4: “Evaṁ, bho”ti kho rosikā nhāpito lohiccassa brāhmaṇassa paṭissutvā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṁ abhivādetvā ekamantaṁ aṭṭhāsi.
root_text.dn12:7.5: Ekamantaṁ ṭhito kho rosikā nhāpito bhagavato kālaṁ ārocesi:
root_text.dn12:7.7: Atha kho bhagavā pubbaṇhasamayaṁ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya saddhiṁ bhikkhusaṅghena yena sālavatikā tenupasaṅkami.
root_text.dn12:8.1: Tena kho pana samayena rosikā nhāpito bhagavantaṁ piṭṭhito piṭṭhito anubandho hoti.
root_text.dn12:8.2: Atha kho rosikā nhāpito bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.dn12:8.3: “lohiccassa, bhante, brāhmaṇassa evarūpaṁ pāpakaṁ diṭṭhigataṁ uppannaṁ:
root_text.dn12:8.4: ‘idha samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā kusalaṁ dhammaṁ adhigaccheyya, kusalaṁ dhammaṁ adhigantvā na parassa āroceyya—
root_text.dn12:8.6: Seyyathāpi nāma purāṇaṁ bandhanaṁ chinditvā aññaṁ navaṁ bandhanaṁ kareyya;
root_text.dn12:8.9: Sādhu, bhante, bhagavā lohiccaṁ brāhmaṇaṁ etasmā pāpakā diṭṭhigatā vivecetū”ti.
root_text.dn12:8.10: “Appeva nāma siyā, rosike, appeva nāma siyā, rosike”ti.
root_text.dn12:9.1: Atha kho bhagavā yena lohiccassa brāhmaṇassa nivesanaṁ tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā paññatte āsane nisīdi.
root_text.dn12:9.2: Atha kho lohicco brāhmaṇo buddhappamukhaṁ bhikkhusaṅghaṁ paṇītena khādanīyena bhojanīyena sahatthā santappesi sampavāresi.
root_text.dn12:9.4: Atha kho lohicco brāhmaṇo bhagavantaṁ bhuttāviṁ onītapattapāṇiṁ aññataraṁ nīcaṁ āsanaṁ gahetvā ekamantaṁ nisīdi.
root_text.dn12:9.5: Ekamantaṁ nisinnaṁ kho lohiccaṁ brāhmaṇaṁ bhagavā etadavoca:
root_text.dn12:9.6: “saccaṁ kira te, lohicca, evarūpaṁ pāpakaṁ diṭṭhigataṁ uppannaṁ:
root_text.dn12:9.7: ‘idha samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā kusalaṁ dhammaṁ adhigaccheyya, kusalaṁ dhammaṁ adhigantvā na parassa āroceyya, kiñhi paro parassa karissati.
root_text.dn12:9.8: Seyyathāpi nāma purāṇaṁ bandhanaṁ chinditvā aññaṁ navaṁ bandhanaṁ kareyya;
root_text.dn12:9.9: evaṁ sampadamidaṁ pāpakaṁ lobhadhammaṁ vadāmi, kiñhi paro parassa karissatī’”ti?
root_text.dn12:10.6: Yā sālavatikāya samudayasañjāti lohiccova taṁ brāhmaṇo ekako paribhuñjeyya, na aññesaṁ dadeyyā’ti.
root_text.dn12:10.7: Evaṁ vādī so ye taṁ upajīvanti, tesaṁ antarāyakaro vā hoti, no vā”ti?
root_text.dn12:10.9: “Antarāyakaro samāno hitānukampī vā tesaṁ hoti ahitānukampī vā”ti?
root_text.dn12:10.11: “Ahitānukampissa mettaṁ vā tesu cittaṁ paccupaṭṭhitaṁ hoti sapattakaṁ vā”ti?
root_text.dn12:10.13: “Sapattake citte paccupaṭṭhite micchādiṭṭhi vā hoti sammādiṭṭhi vā”ti?
root_text.dn12:10.15: “Micchādiṭṭhissa kho ahaṁ, lohicca, dvinnaṁ gatīnaṁ aññataraṁ gatiṁ vadāmi—
root_text.dn12:11.2: nanu rājā pasenadi kosalo kāsikosalaṁ ajjhāvasatī”ti?
root_text.dn12:11.6: yā kāsikosale samudayasañjāti, rājāva taṁ pasenadi kosalo ekako paribhuñjeyya, na aññesaṁ dadeyyā’ti.
root_text.dn12:11.7: Evaṁ vādī so ye rājānaṁ pasenadiṁ kosalaṁ upajīvanti tumhe ceva aññe ca, tesaṁ antarāyakaro vā hoti, no vā”ti?
root_text.dn12:11.9: “Antarāyakaro samāno hitānukampī vā tesaṁ hoti ahitānukampī vā”ti?
root_text.dn12:11.11: “Ahitānukampissa mettaṁ vā tesu cittaṁ paccupaṭṭhitaṁ hoti sapattakaṁ vā”ti?
root_text.dn12:11.13: “Sapattake citte paccupaṭṭhite micchādiṭṭhi vā hoti sammādiṭṭhi vā”ti?
root_text.dn12:11.15: “Micchādiṭṭhissa kho ahaṁ, lohicca, dvinnaṁ gatīnaṁ aññataraṁ gatiṁ vadāmi—
root_text.dn12:12.1: Iti kira, lohicca, yo evaṁ vadeyya:
root_text.dn12:12.3: yā sālavatikāya samudayasañjāti, lohiccova taṁ brāhmaṇo ekako paribhuñjeyya, na aññesaṁ dadeyyā’ti.
root_text.dn12:13.1: Evaṁvādī so ye taṁ upajīvanti, tesaṁ antarāyakaro hoti.
root_text.dn12:13.2: Antarāyakaro samāno ahitānukampī hoti, ahitānukampissa sapattakaṁ cittaṁ paccupaṭṭhitaṁ hoti, sapattake citte paccupaṭṭhite micchādiṭṭhi hoti.
root_text.dn12:13.3: Evameva kho, lohicca, yo evaṁ vadeyya:
root_text.dn12:13.4: ‘idha samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā kusalaṁ dhammaṁ adhigaccheyya, kusalaṁ dhammaṁ adhigantvā na parassa āroceyya, kiñhi paro parassa karissati.
root_text.dn12:13.5: Seyyathāpi nāma purāṇaṁ bandhanaṁ chinditvā aññaṁ navaṁ bandhanaṁ kareyya …pe…
root_text.dn12:13.7: Evaṁvādī so ye te kulaputtā tathāgatappaveditaṁ dhammavinayaṁ āgamma evarūpaṁ uḷāraṁ visesaṁ adhigacchanti, sotāpattiphalampi sacchikaronti, sakadāgāmiphalampi sacchikaronti, anāgāmiphalampi sacchikaronti, arahattampi sacchikaronti, ye cime dibbā gabbhā paripācenti dibbānaṁ bhavānaṁ abhinibbattiyā, tesaṁ antarāyakaro hoti, antarāyakaro samāno ahitānukampī hoti, ahitānukampissa sapattakaṁ cittaṁ paccupaṭṭhitaṁ hoti, sapattake citte paccupaṭṭhite micchādiṭṭhi hoti.
root_text.dn12:13.8: Micchādiṭṭhissa kho ahaṁ, lohicca, dvinnaṁ gatīnaṁ aññataraṁ gatiṁ vadāmi—
root_text.dn12:14.1: Iti kira, lohicca, yo evaṁ vadeyya:
root_text.dn12:14.3: yā kāsikosale samudayasañjāti, rājāva taṁ pasenadi kosalo ekako paribhuñjeyya, na aññesaṁ dadeyyā’ti.
root_text.dn12:15.1: Evaṁvādī so ye rājānaṁ pasenadiṁ kosalaṁ upajīvanti tumhe ceva aññe ca, tesaṁ antarāyakaro hoti.
root_text.dn12:15.2: Antarāyakaro samāno ahitānukampī hoti, ahitānukampissa sapattakaṁ cittaṁ paccupaṭṭhitaṁ hoti, sapattake citte paccupaṭṭhite micchādiṭṭhi hoti.
root_text.dn12:15.3: Evameva kho, lohicca, yo evaṁ vadeyya:
root_text.dn12:15.4: ‘idha samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā kusalaṁ dhammaṁ adhigaccheyya, kusalaṁ dhammaṁ adhigantvā na parassa āroceyya, kiñhi paro parassa karissati.
root_text.dn12:15.7: Evaṁvādī so ye te kulaputtā tathāgatappaveditaṁ dhammavinayaṁ āgamma evarūpaṁ uḷāraṁ visesaṁ adhigacchanti, sotāpattiphalampi sacchikaronti, sakadāgāmiphalampi sacchikaronti, anāgāmiphalampi sacchikaronti, arahattampi sacchikaronti.
root_text.dn12:15.8: Ye cime dibbā gabbhā paripācenti dibbānaṁ bhavānaṁ abhinibbattiyā, tesaṁ antarāyakaro hoti,
root_text.dn12:15.9: antarāyakaro samāno ahitānukampī hoti, ahitānukampissa sapattakaṁ cittaṁ paccupaṭṭhitaṁ hoti, sapattake citte paccupaṭṭhite micchādiṭṭhi hoti.
root_text.dn12:15.10: Micchādiṭṭhissa kho ahaṁ, lohicca, dvinnaṁ gatīnaṁ aññataraṁ gatiṁ vadāmi—
root_text.dn12:16.1: Tayo khome, lohicca, satthāro, ye loke codanārahā;
root_text.dn12:16.2: yo ca panevarūpe satthāro codeti, sā codanā bhūtā tacchā dhammikā anavajjā.
root_text.dn12:16.4: Idha, lohicca, ekacco satthā yassatthāya agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajito hoti, svāssa sāmaññattho ananuppatto hoti.
root_text.dn12:16.5: So taṁ sāmaññatthaṁ ananupāpuṇitvā sāvakānaṁ dhammaṁ deseti:
root_text.dn12:16.7: Tassa sāvakā na sussūsanti, na sotaṁ odahanti, na aññā cittaṁ upaṭṭhapenti, vokkamma ca satthusāsanā vattanti.
root_text.dn12:16.9: ‘āyasmā kho yassatthāya agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajito, so te sāmaññattho ananuppatto, taṁ tvaṁ sāmaññatthaṁ ananupāpuṇitvā sāvakānaṁ dhammaṁ desesi:
root_text.dn12:16.11: Tassa te sāvakā na sussūsanti, na sotaṁ odahanti, na aññā cittaṁ upaṭṭhapenti, vokkamma ca satthusāsanā vattanti.
root_text.dn12:16.12: Seyyathāpi nāma osakkantiyā vā ussakkeyya, parammukhiṁ vā āliṅgeyya;
root_text.dn12:16.15: Ayaṁ kho, lohicca, paṭhamo satthā, yo loke codanāraho;
root_text.dn12:16.16: yo ca panevarūpaṁ satthāraṁ codeti, sā codanā bhūtā tacchā dhammikā anavajjā.
root_text.dn12:17.1: Puna caparaṁ, lohicca, idhekacco satthā yassatthāya agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajito hoti, svāssa sāmaññattho ananuppatto hoti.
root_text.dn12:17.2: So taṁ sāmaññatthaṁ ananupāpuṇitvā sāvakānaṁ dhammaṁ deseti:
root_text.dn12:17.4: Tassa sāvakā sussūsanti, sotaṁ odahanti, aññā cittaṁ upaṭṭhapenti, na ca vokkamma satthusāsanā vattanti.
root_text.dn12:17.6: ‘āyasmā kho yassatthāya agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajito, so te sāmaññattho ananuppatto. Taṁ tvaṁ sāmaññatthaṁ ananupāpuṇitvā sāvakānaṁ dhammaṁ desesi:
root_text.dn12:17.8: Tassa te sāvakā sussūsanti, sotaṁ odahanti, aññā cittaṁ upaṭṭhapenti, na ca vokkamma satthusāsanā vattanti.
root_text.dn12:17.9: Seyyathāpi nāma sakaṁ khettaṁ ohāya paraṁ khettaṁ niddāyitabbaṁ maññeyya, evaṁ sampadamidaṁ pāpakaṁ lobhadhammaṁ vadāmi—kiñhi paro parassa karissatī’ti.
root_text.dn12:17.10: Ayaṁ kho, lohicca, dutiyo satthā, yo, loke codanāraho;
root_text.dn12:17.11: yo ca panevarūpaṁ satthāraṁ codeti, sā codanā bhūtā tacchā dhammikā anavajjā.
root_text.dn12:18.1: Puna caparaṁ, lohicca, idhekacco satthā yassatthāya agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajito hoti, svāssa sāmaññattho anuppatto hoti.
root_text.dn12:18.2: So taṁ sāmaññatthaṁ anupāpuṇitvā sāvakānaṁ dhammaṁ deseti:
root_text.dn12:18.4: Tassa sāvakā na sussūsanti, na sotaṁ odahanti, na aññā cittaṁ upaṭṭhapenti, vokkamma ca satthusāsanā vattanti.
root_text.dn12:18.6: ‘āyasmā kho yassatthāya agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajito, so te sāmaññattho anuppatto.
root_text.dn12:18.7: Taṁ tvaṁ sāmaññatthaṁ anupāpuṇitvā sāvakānaṁ dhammaṁ desesi:
root_text.dn12:18.9: Tassa te sāvakā na sussūsanti, na sotaṁ odahanti, na aññā cittaṁ upaṭṭhapenti, vokkamma ca satthusāsanā vattanti.
root_text.dn12:18.10: Seyyathāpi nāma purāṇaṁ bandhanaṁ chinditvā aññaṁ navaṁ bandhanaṁ kareyya;
root_text.dn12:18.11: evaṁ sampadamidaṁ pāpakaṁ lobhadhammaṁ vadāmi, kiñhi paro parassa karissatī’ti.
root_text.dn12:18.12: Ayaṁ kho, lohicca, tatiyo satthā, yo loke codanāraho;
root_text.dn12:18.13: yo ca panevarūpaṁ satthāraṁ codeti, sā codanā bhūtā tacchā dhammikā anavajjā.
root_text.dn12:18.14: Ime kho, lohicca, tayo satthāro, ye loke codanārahā,
root_text.dn12:18.15: yo ca panevarūpe satthāro codeti, sā codanā bhūtā tacchā dhammikā anavajjā”ti.
root_text.dn12:19.1: Evaṁ vutte, lohicco brāhmaṇo bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.dn12:19.2: “atthi pana, bho gotama, koci satthā, yo loke nacodanāraho”ti?
root_text.dn12:19.3: “Atthi kho, lohicca, satthā, yo loke nacodanāraho”ti.
root_text.dn12:19.4: “Katamo pana so, bho gotama, satthā, yo loke nacodanāraho”ti?
root_text.dn12:20-55.1: “Idha, lohicca, tathāgato loke uppajjati arahaṁ, sammāsambuddho …pe…
root_text.dn12:20-55.2: Evaṁ kho, lohicca, bhikkhu sīlasampanno hoti …pe…
root_text.dn12:20-55.4: yasmiṁ kho, lohicca, satthari sāvako evarūpaṁ uḷāraṁ visesaṁ adhigacchati, ayampi kho, lohicca, satthā, yo loke nacodanāraho.
root_text.dn12:20-55.5: Yo ca panevarūpaṁ satthāraṁ codeti, sā codanā abhūtā atacchā adhammikā sāvajjā.

root_text.dn12:78.1: Evaṁ vutte, lohicco brāhmaṇo bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.dn12:78.2: “seyyathāpi, bho gotama, puriso purisaṁ narakapapātaṁ patantaṁ kesesu gahetvā uddharitvā thale patiṭṭhapeyya;
root_text.dn12:78.3: evamevāhaṁ bhotā gotamena narakapapātaṁ papatanto uddharitvā thale patiṭṭhāpito.
root_text.dn12:78.4: Abhikkantaṁ, bho gotama, abhikkantaṁ, bho gotama.
root_text.dn12:78.5: Seyyathāpi, bho gotama, nikkujjitaṁ vā ukkujjeyya, paṭicchannaṁ vā vivareyya, mūḷhassa vā maggaṁ ācikkheyya, andhakāre vā telapajjotaṁ dhāreyya: ‘cakkhumanto rūpāni dakkhantī’ti; evamevaṁ bhotā gotamena anekapariyāyena dhammo pakāsito.
root_text.dn12:78.6: Esāhaṁ bhavantaṁ gotamaṁ saraṇaṁ gacchāmi dhammañca bhikkhusaṅghañca.
root_text.dn12:78.7: Upāsakaṁ maṁ bhavaṁ gotamo dhāretu ajjatagge pāṇupetaṁ saraṇaṁ gatan”ti.

translation_text.dn12:1.2: At one time the Buddha was wandering in the land of the Kosalans together with a large Saṅgha of five hundred mendicants when he arrived at Sālavatikā.
translation_text.dn12:1.3: Now at that time the brahmin Lohicca was living in Sālavatikā. It was a crown property given by King Pasenadi of Kosala, teeming with living creatures, full of hay, wood, water, and grain, a royal park endowed to a brahmin.
translation_text.dn12:2.1: Now at that time Lohicca had the following harmful misconception:
translation_text.dn12:2.2: “Should an ascetic or brahmin achieve some skillful quality, they ought not inform anyone else. For what can one person do for another?
translation_text.dn12:2.3: Suppose someone cut off an old bond, only to create another new bond.
translation_text.dn12:2.4: That’s the consequence of such a wicked, greedy deed, I say. For what can one person do for another?”
translation_text.dn12:3.2: “It seems the ascetic Gotama—a Sakyan, gone forth from a Sakyan family—has arrived at Sālavatikā, together with a large Saṅgha of five hundred mendicants.
translation_text.dn12:3.4: ‘That Blessed One is perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those fit for training, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.’
translation_text.dn12:3.5: He has realized with his own insight this world—with its gods, Māras, and divinities, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, gods and humans—and he makes it known to others.
translation_text.dn12:3.6: He proclaims a teaching that is good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased. And he reveals a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure.
translation_text.dn12:3.7: It’s good to see such perfected ones.”
translation_text.dn12:4.1: Then Lohicca addressed his barber Rosika,
translation_text.dn12:4.2: “Here, dear Rosika, go to the ascetic Gotama and in my name bow with your head to his feet. Ask him if he is healthy and well, nimble, strong, and living comfortably.
translation_text.dn12:4.4: And then ask him whether he,
translation_text.dn12:4.5: together with the mendicant Saṅgha, might please accept tomorrow’s meal from the brahmin Lohicca.”
translation_text.dn12:5.1: “Yes, worthy sir,” Rosika replied. He did as he was asked, and
translation_text.dn12:6.1: Then, knowing that the Buddha had consented, Rosika got up from his seat, went to Lohicca, and said to him,
translation_text.dn12:7.1: And when the night had passed Lohicca had delicious fresh and cooked foods prepared in his own home. Then he had the Buddha informed of the time, saying,
translation_text.dn12:7.2: “Here, dear Rosika, go to the ascetic Gotama and announce the time, saying:
translation_text.dn12:7.3: ‘It’s time, worthy Gotama, the meal is ready.’”
translation_text.dn12:7.4: “Yes, worthy sir,” Rosika replied. He did as he was asked.
translation_text.dn12:7.7: Then the Buddha robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, went to Sālavatikā together with the Saṅgha of mendicants.
translation_text.dn12:8.1: Now, Rosika was following behind the Buddha,
translation_text.dn12:8.2: and told him of Lohicca’s views, adding,
translation_text.dn12:8.9: “Sir, please dissuade him from that harmful misconception.”
translation_text.dn12:8.10: “Hopefully that’ll happen, Rosika, hopefully that’ll happen.”
translation_text.dn12:9.1: Then the Buddha approached Lohicca’s home, where he sat on the seat spread out.
translation_text.dn12:9.2: Then Lohicca served and satisfied the mendicant Saṅgha headed by the Buddha with his own hands with delicious fresh and cooked foods.
translation_text.dn12:9.4: When the Buddha had eaten and washed his hand and bowl, Lohicca took a low seat and sat to one side.
translation_text.dn12:9.6: “Is it really true, Lohicca, that you have such a harmful misconception:
translation_text.dn12:9.7: ‘Should an ascetic or brahmin achieve some skillful quality, they ought not inform anyone else. For what can one person do for another?
translation_text.dn12:9.8: Suppose someone cut off an old bond, only to create another new bond.
translation_text.dn12:9.9: That’s the consequence of such a wicked, greedy deed, I say. For what can one person do for another?’”
translation_text.dn12:10.6: He alone should enjoy the revenues produced in Sālavatikā and not share them with anyone else.’
translation_text.dn12:10.7: Would the one who spoke like that make it difficult for those whose living depends on you or not?”
translation_text.dn12:10.9: “But is someone who creates difficulties for others acting kindly or unkindly?”
translation_text.dn12:10.11: “But does an unkind person have love in their heart or hostility?”
translation_text.dn12:10.13: “And when the heart is full of hostility, is there right view or wrong view?”
translation_text.dn12:10.15: “An individual with wrong view is reborn in one of two places, I say:
translation_text.dn12:11.2: Does King Pasenadi reign over Kāsi and Kosala?”
translation_text.dn12:11.5: ‘King Pasenadi reigns over Kāsi and Kosala.
translation_text.dn12:11.6: He alone should enjoy the revenues produced in Kāsi and Kosala and not share them with anyone else.’
translation_text.dn12:11.7: Would the one who spoke like that make it difficult for yourself and others whose living depends on King Pasenadi or not?”
translation_text.dn12:11.9: “But is someone who creates difficulties for others acting kindly or unkindly?”
translation_text.dn12:11.11: “But does an unkind person have love in their heart or hostility?”
translation_text.dn12:11.13: “And when the heart is full of hostility, is there right view or wrong view?”
translation_text.dn12:11.15: “An individual with wrong view is reborn in one of two places, I say:
translation_text.dn12:12.1: So it seems, Lohicca, that should someone say such a thing either of Lohicca or of King Pasenadi,
translation_text.dn12:13.3: In the same way, suppose someone were to say:
translation_text.dn12:13.4: ‘Should an ascetic or brahmin achieve some skillful quality, they ought not inform anyone else. For what can one person do for another?
translation_text.dn12:13.5: Suppose someone cut off an old bond, only to create another new bond.
translation_text.dn12:13.6: That’s the consequence of such a wicked, greedy deed, I say. For what can one person do for another?’
translation_text.dn12:13.7: Now, there are gentlemen who, relying on the teaching and training proclaimed by the Realized One, achieve a high distinction such as the following: they realize the fruit of stream-entry, the fruit of once-return, the fruit of non-return, or perfection. And in addition, there are those who ripen the seeds for rebirth in a heavenly state. The person who spoke like that makes it difficult for them. They’re acting unkindly, their heart is full of hostility, and they have wrong view.
translation_text.dn12:13.8: An individual with wrong view is reborn in one of two places, I say:
translation_text.dn12:16.0: 2. Three Teachers Who Deserve to Be Reprimanded
translation_text.dn12:16.1: Lohicca, there are three kinds of teachers in the world who deserve to be reprimanded.
translation_text.dn12:16.2: When someone reprimands such teachers, the reprimand is true, correct, legitimate, and blameless.
translation_text.dn12:16.4: Firstly, take a teacher who has not reached the goal of the ascetic life for which they went forth from the lay life to homelessness.
translation_text.dn12:16.6: ‘This is for your welfare. This is for your happiness.’
translation_text.dn12:16.7: But their disciples don’t want to listen. They don’t actively listen or try to understand. They proceed having turned away from the teacher’s instruction.
translation_text.dn12:16.8: That teacher deserves to be reprimanded:
translation_text.dn12:16.9: ‘Venerable, you haven’t reached the goal of the ascetic life; and when you teach disciples
translation_text.dn12:16.11: they proceed having turned away from the teacher’s instruction.
translation_text.dn12:16.12: It’s like a man who makes advances on a woman though she pulls away, or embraces her though she turns her back.
translation_text.dn12:16.13: That’s the consequence of such a wicked, greedy deed, I say. For what can one do for another?’
translation_text.dn12:16.15: This is the first kind of teacher who deserves to be reprimanded.
translation_text.dn12:17.1: Furthermore, take a teacher who has not reached the goal of the ascetic life for which they went forth from the lay life to homelessness.
translation_text.dn12:17.3: ‘This is for your welfare. This is for your happiness.’
translation_text.dn12:17.4: Their disciples do want to listen. They actively listen and try to understand. They don’t proceed having turned away from the teacher’s instruction.
translation_text.dn12:17.5: That teacher deserves to be reprimanded:
translation_text.dn12:17.6: ‘Venerable, you haven’t reached the goal of the ascetic life; and when you teach disciples
translation_text.dn12:17.8: they don’t proceed having turned away from the teacher’s instruction.
translation_text.dn12:17.9: It’s like someone who abandons their own field and presumes to weed someone else’s field. That’s the consequence of such a wicked, greedy deed, I say. For what can one do for another?’
translation_text.dn12:17.10: This is the second kind of teacher who deserves to be reprimanded.
translation_text.dn12:18.1: Furthermore, take a teacher who has reached the goal of the ascetic life for which they went forth from the lay life to homelessness.
translation_text.dn12:18.3: ‘This is for your welfare. This is for your happiness.’
translation_text.dn12:18.4: But their disciples don’t want to listen. They don’t actively listen or try to understand. They proceed having turned away from the teacher’s instruction.
translation_text.dn12:18.5: That teacher deserves to be reprimanded:
translation_text.dn12:18.6: ‘Venerable, you have reached the goal of the ascetic life; yet when you teach disciples
translation_text.dn12:18.9: they proceed having turned away from the teacher’s instruction.
translation_text.dn12:18.10: Suppose someone cut off an old bond, only to create another new bond.
translation_text.dn12:18.11: That’s the consequence of such a wicked, greedy deed, I say. For what can one person do for another?’
translation_text.dn12:18.12: This is the third kind of teacher who deserves to be reprimanded.
translation_text.dn12:18.14: These are the three kinds of teachers in the world who deserve to be reprimanded.
translation_text.dn12:18.15: When someone reprimands such teachers, the reprimand is true, correct, legitimate, and blameless.”
translation_text.dn12:19.0: 3. A Teacher Who Does Not Deserve to Be Reprimanded
translation_text.dn12:19.1: When he had spoken, Lohicca said to the Buddha,
translation_text.dn12:19.2: “But worthy Gotama, is there a teacher in the world who does not deserve to be reprimanded?”
translation_text.dn12:20-55.1: “It’s when a Realized One arises in the world, perfected, a fully awakened Buddha …
translation_text.dn12:20-55.2: That’s how a mendicant is accomplished in ethics. …
translation_text.dn12:20-55.3: They enter and remain in the first absorption …
translation_text.dn12:20-55.4: A teacher under whom a disciple achieves such a high distinction is one who does not deserve to be reprimanded.
translation_text.dn12:20-55.5: When someone reprimands such a teacher, the reprimand is false, baseless, illegitimate, and blameworthy.
translation_text.dn12:56-62.2: They enter and remain in the second absorption …
translation_text.dn12:56-62.5: A teacher under whom a disciple achieves such a high distinction is one who does not deserve to be reprimanded. …
translation_text.dn12:63-77.2: They project and extend the mind toward knowledge and vision …
translation_text.dn12:63-77.3: A teacher under whom a disciple achieves such a high distinction is one who does not deserve to be reprimanded. …
translation_text.dn12:63-77.5: They understand: ‘… there is nothing further for this place.’
translation_text.dn12:63-77.6: A teacher under whom a disciple achieves such a high distinction is one who does not deserve to be reprimanded. When someone reprimands such a teacher, the reprimand is false, baseless, illegitimate, and blameworthy.”
translation_text.dn12:78.1: When he had spoken, Lohicca said to the Buddha:
translation_text.dn12:78.2: “Suppose, Mister Gotama, a person was falling over a cliff, and another person were to grab them by the hair, pull them up, and place them on solid ground.
translation_text.dn12:78.3: In the same way, when I was falling off a cliff Mister Gotama pulled me up and placed me on solid ground.
translation_text.dn12:78.5: As if he were righting the overturned, or revealing the hidden, or pointing out the path to the lost, or lighting a lamp in the dark so people with clear eyes can see what’s there, worthy Gotama has made the Teaching clear in many ways.
translation_text.dn12:78.6: I go for refuge to the worthy Gotama, to the teaching, and to the mendicant Saṅgha.
translation_text.dn12:78.7: From this day forth, may the worthy Gotama remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”
